home.description: I'm an astronomer at the The Center for Astrochemical Studies of the Max Planck Institute for Extraterrestrial Physics. Previously I was at the UK ALMA Regional Center in Manchester (UK), with an ESO ALMA COFUND fellowship and later at Institute for Astronomy of the ETH Zürich. I am interested in the star formation process, starting from large scales (molecular clouds) down to the protoplanetary disks. In particular, I focus on using the gas kinematics to understand the physical processes behind star formation. For this I also use astrochemistry as a tool to guide the planification and analysis of observations. Before moving to the UK I obtained a PhD in Astronomy from Harvard University, and before that my BSc and MSc in Astronomy from Universidad de Chile. As a PhD student, I worked as part of the COMPLETE survey with my advisor Alyssa Goodman.
home.highlight: Interests: Star formation; gas kinematics; interferometry and image analysis; astrostatistics; astrochemistry.

research.title: Assembling the Star- and Planet-Formation Puzzle

papers.abstract: I strive for obtaining a better understanding of star- and planet-forming systems using astronomical observations. Sometimes this involves using new instruments or facilities to explore the formation process in a new way. Other times it involves using a new analysis technique or a systematic analysis of large datasets. In particular, I focus on studying the kinematics of regions using different molecular tracers, depending on the question to be addressed.

papers.title: Direct Observation of a Sharp Transition to Coherence in Dense Cores.
papers.abstract: Thanks to the large area and high sensitivity of the observations of the Barnard5 region, we detect (for the first time) of the transition between the coherent core and the dense but more turbulent gas surrounding it. This transition is sharp, increasing the velocity dispersion by a factor of 2 in less than 0.04 pc. The existence of the transition provides a natural definition of dense core: the region with nearly constant subsonic non-thermal velocity dispersion.
